rewrite.title: Buffett Cuts $1.7B Amazon Stake, Shifts to Traditional Sectors
rewrite.body:
On February 17, 2026, Berkshire Hathaway disclosed a major portfolio reshuffle in its latest 13-F filing, notably slashing its Amazon stake by 77%, equivalent to selling 7.7 million shares valued near $1.7 billion. This decisive reduction marks a strategic retreat from the e-commerce giant after seven years of holding the stock, reflecting Warren Buffett’s renewed focus on sectors historically favored for their resilience.

Simultaneously, Berkshire initiated a fresh $352 million investment in The New York Times, acquiring 5 million shares and triggering a roughly 10% jump in the publisher’s stock price. The firm also pared down its Apple holdings to a modest 1.5% stake, further signaling a pullback from large technology companies.

In contrast, Berkshire expanded its footprint in more traditional industries, increasing positions in insurer Chubb and energy leader Chevron. The conglomerate also committed to a $9.7 billion acquisition of Occidental Petroleum’s petrochemical business and amassed a $5.6 billion stake in Google, illustrating a nuanced approach that balances tech exposure with stable, cash-generative businesses.

These moves collectively indicate Buffett’s intent to fortify Berkshire’s portfolio against potential economic headwinds by emphasizing durable, cash-flow-rich companies over high-growth tech stocks. The shift underscores a broader investment philosophy recalibration as market conditions evolve.
